questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of involvement of mucoceles of sinuses in decreasing order?
questions.solution:
Mucocele is a local complication of chronic rhinosinusitis. The sinuses affected in decreasing order of frequency are:

Frontal>ethmoid>maxillary>sphenoid. Thus option A is correct answer.

Etiology: 1) Chronic obstruction to sinus ostium resulting in accumulation of secretions which slowly expands.

2) Cystic dilatation of mucous gland of sinus mucosa due to obstruction of duct.

Mucocele of frontal sinus the swelling is cystic and non tender patient complains mild headache, diplopia and proptosis. Treatment is fronto-ethmoidectomy with drainage into middle meatus.

Mucocele of ethmoid sinus : Causes expansion of medial wall of orbit. Treatment is Intranasal drainage.

Mucocele of maxillary sinus: presents as retention cyst due to obstruction of the seromucinous glands. No treatment is generally required in most case.

Mucocele of sphenoid sinus: destruction of posterior ethmoid and sphenoid sinus Exopthalmos is presents cranial nerve 3 4 and 6 may get involved. External ethmoidectomy and sphenoidectomy is needed.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Mucocele is a local complication of chronic rhinosinusitis. The sinuses affected in decreasing order of frequency are: Frontal>ethmoid>maxillary>sphenoid.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:231.

questions.text: MELP, TONES, Lynch howarth approach are the techniques that can be used for managing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mucocele is a local complication of chronic rhinosinusitis. The sinuses affected in decreasing order of frequency are:

Frontal>ethmoid>maxillary>sphenoid.

Etiology: 1) Chronic obstruction to sinus ostium resulting in accumulation of secretions which slowly expands.

2) Cystic dilatation of mucous gland of sinus mucosa due to obstruction of duct.

Mucocele of frontal sinus the swelling is cystic and non tender patient complains mild headache, diplopia and proptosis. Treatment is fronto-ethmoidectomy with drainage into middle meatus. MELP (modified endoscopic lothorp procedure), TONES (Trans orbital Neuro endoscopic surgery),and Lynch Howarth procedure are performed for frontal sinus mucocele clearance thus option A is correct.

Mucocele of ethmoid sinus : Causes expansion of medial wall of orbit. Treatment is Intranasal drainage.

Mucocele of maxillary sinus: presents as retention cyst due to obstruction of the seromucinous glands. No treatment is generally required in most case.

Mucocele of sphenoid sinus: destruction of posterior ethmoid and sphenoid sinus Exopthalmos is presents cranial nerve 3 ,4 and 6 may get involved. External ethmoidectomy and sphenoidectomy is needed.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:231.

questions.text: The wavelength of carbon dioxide laser is?
questions.solution:
Laser is an acronym for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emissions of Radiation. Different types of lasers are used with different wavelength. Lasing medium can be solid (ruby, Nd: YAG, or potassium titanyl phosphate), Gas( CO2, or helium neon ) or liquid (pumped inorganic dye in a glass tube).


Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:413.

questions.text: The cardinal symptoms of chronic rhinosinusitis includes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
• The cardinal features of chronic rhinosinusitis include paroxysmal sneezing, 10- 20 Sneezes at a time, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge and itching of the nose. Thus option A B and D are true.
  • Itching may also involve eyes, palate or pharynx. Duration and severity may vary with season. Fever is not a feature of Allergic rhinosinusitis. Thus option C is correct answer here.
  • Signs includes :
    • nasal signs such as transverse nasal crease, pale edematous nasal mucosa, turbinates are swollen.
    • Ocular signs include edema of eyelids, congestion and cobble stone appearance of conjunctiva,
    • otological signs include retraction of tympanic membrane.
    • Pharyngeal signs include granular pharyngitis due to hyperplasia of submucosal tissue.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:195.

questions.text: What is the medial limit of Draf 2b surgery?
questions.solution: Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:495.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve passes through sphenopalatine foramen?
questions.solution:
• The sphenopalatine foramen (SPF) represents an opening on the lateral nasal wall that is present at the articulation between the superior aspect of the vertical portion of the palatine bone and the inferior projection of the sphenoid bone.
  • The sphenopalatine foramen connects the nasal cavity to the pterygopalatine fossa of the skull and houses the sphenopalatine artery (SPA) and vein, the posterior superior lateral nasal nerve, and the nasopalatine nerves.
  • Moreover, the sphenopalatine foramen provides an important anatomical landmark for those who perform procedures where knowledge of the sphenopalatine foramen and its contents remains critical, including the creation of a nasoseptal flap for nasal reconstruction or skull base repairs, posterior epistaxis control, and functional endoscopic sinonasal surgery.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:218-219.

• Lupus pernio is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis, which was first described in 1889 by Ernest Besnier. It presents as a violaceous lesion or shiny nodules over the head and neck but is predominantly localized to the nose, cheeks, and ears. Thus option B is correct.
  • Cutaneous manifestations of sarcoidosis are estimated to occur in approximately 25 percent of patients and the skin lesions help establish the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
  • Lupus pernio can present either as an isolated skin lesion or it can be an early manifestation of systemic sarcoidosis. Lupus pernio is often a predictor of systemic sarcoidosis, which warrants thorough workup.
  • Patients with lupus pernio have a higher risk for pulmonary disease, which was confirmed in a retrospective study of 516 patients with sarcoidosis.

Pulmonary parenchymal involvement was present more often in patients with lupus pernio or sarcoidosis involving scar tissue (64 and 40 percent, respectively) compared to patients with erythema nodosum or other skin lesions of sarcoidosis.

Tuberculosis is characterized by Lupus vulgaris. Syphilis presents with saddle nose deformity, snuffels. Thus option A C and D are not true.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:187.

questions.text: Lateral osteotomies fractures which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
Types of osteotomies in rhinoplasty include the following:

Lateral osteotomies - These are performed along the frontal process of the maxilla, occasionally extending onto the nasal bone. Thus option c is true.

Medial osteotomies - These are performed to help ensure that fracture lines occur as desired by the surgeon; they may be desirable if infracturing is difficult with a lateral osteotomy

Superior osteotomies - These may be performed when the nasal bones are unusually thick and concern for an unfavorable fracture line connecting the lateral and medial fracture lines exists. Thus option A is not true.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:495.

questions.text: All of the following are the major criteria in the Bent and kuhn criteria for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis except?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) is an inflammatory disorder of the upper respiratory tract resulting from type 1 and 3 hypersensitivity reactions against fungi.

The Bent and Kuhn diagnostic criteria, which were reported in 1994 and are widely used for diagnosis of AFRS, is composed of the following five criteria:

1) type 1 hypersensitivity to fungi confirmed by history, skin testing, or serology;

2) nasal polyposis;

3) characteristic signs on computed tomography (CT) described as serpiginous areas of increased attenuation;

4) eosinophilic mucus without fungal invasion of sinus tissue;

5) positive fungal stain of sinus contents removed during surgery.


Among these items, nasal polyposis is not always present, and the guideline issued by five US national societies specifies edema of the middle meatus or ethmoid area or nasal polyps. Thus option d is not true.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:229.

choices.text: Tier of cells above the agger nasi
A single large supra agger cell
Frontal cells that pneumatize into Frontal sinus and extends by more than 50% of the vertical height of the frontal sinus

questions.text: According to international Frontal sinus anatomy classification type 3 cells are?
questions.solution:
Bent and Kuhn Classification of Frontal Sinus Cells:

Type 1: A single air cell above the agger nasi cell

Type 2: Two or more air cells above the agger nasi cell

Type 3: A single large cell above the agger nasi cell that extends into the frontal sinus

Type 4: Cells are entirely contained within the frontal sinus.

Reference : Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th Edition, Page Number:218.

questions.text: The most frequent acute complications of ethmoid sinusitis is ?
questions.solution:
Complications of sinusitis are rare occurring in about 1 out of every 1000 cases. Sinus infections may spread to the orbit, bone, or intracranial cavities.

Eighty percent of orbitocranial complications occur in the orbit. These complications can come with significant morbidity and mortality. The orbit is the most common site due to the very thin ethmoid bone that separates infections from the ethmoid to the orbit. Among the orbit Orbital cellulitis is the most common complication. Thus option B is true.

The Chandler classification is the most common method or grading orbital complications of sinusitis infection (listed from least to most severe).

  1. Preseptal cellulitis
  2. Orbital cellulitis
  3. Subperiosteal abscess
  4. Orbital abscess
  5. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Intracranial complications can also occur but are rare. Thus option c and D are not true here. These include the development of a subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, meningitis, or a subdural empyema (the latter comes with a high mortality rate).

Pott puffy tumor is a subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone, usually associated with osteomyelitis. This is also a relatively rare complication. Both complications typically arise from frontal sinus infections, via hematogenous spread through the valveless diploic vein system.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:232- 233- 234.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for diagnosis of Wegner's granulomatosis as per American society of Rheumatology 1990?
questions.solution:
2022 criteria for the classification of granulomatosis with polyangiitis

These criteria from the American College of Rheumatology and the European Alliance of Associations for Rheumatology are used for enrolling patients in studies and should not be considered as diagnostic criteria. The classification criteria should be used when a diagnosis of small- or medium-vessel vasculitis has been made, and alternative disorders mimicking vasculitis have been excluded. The criteria are divided into clinical criteria and laboratory, imaging, and biopsy criteria. Each criterion is assigned a score.

Clinical criteria and scores are as follows:

Nasal involvement – Bloody discharge, ulcers, crusting, congestion, blockage, or septal defect/perforation: +3

Cartilaginous involvement – Inflammation of ear or nose cartilage, hoarse voice or stridor, endobronchial involvement, or saddle nose deformity: +2

Conductive or sensorineural hearing loss: +1

Laboratory, imaging, and biopsy criteria and scores are as follows:

Positive test for cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA) or antiproteinase 3 (anti-PR3) antibodies: +5

Pulmonary nodules, mass, or cavitation on chest imaging: +2

Granuloma, extravascular granulomatous inflammation, or giant cells on biopsy: +2

Inflammation, consolidation, or effusion of the nasal/paranasal sinuses, or mastoiditis on imaging: +1

Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis on biopsy: +1

Positive test for perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) or antimyeloperoxidase (anti-MPO) antibodies: -1

Blood eosinophil count ≥ 1 × 10 9/L: -4

For the purposes of classification, a patient with a total score of 5 or more is said to have GPA. These criteria have a sensitivity of 92.5% and a specificity of 93.8%.

Tag1 : Nose, Granulomatous conditions

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:187.

choices.text: A disorder where all odours smell the same
A decline in the sense of smell
Dislike or fear of certain smell
A distorted or perverted sense of smell perception to odour stimulation

questions.solution:
Osmophobia, defined as a fear, aversion, or psychological hypersensitivity to odors, is a very rare isolated phobia. It is common among primary headache patients, with prevalence of migraine.

Its inclusion among diagnostic criteria was suggested, based on evidence of specificity for migraine diagnosis, greater than photophobia and phonophobia In fact, the isolated presence of osmophobia during headache attacks should be considered a diagnostic criterion.

People who have a smell disorder either have a decrease in their ability to smell or changes in the way they perceive odors.

Hyposmia is a reduced ability to detect odors.

Anosmia is the complete inability to detect odors. In rare cases, someone may be born without a sense of smell, a condition called congenital anosmia.

Parosmia is a change in the normal perception of odors, such as when the smell of something familiar is distorted, or when something that normally smells pleasant now smells foul.

Phantosmia is the sensation of an odor that isn't there.

Tag1 : Nose, Disorders of smell

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:164.

questions.text: A local anesthetic which is not used for topical anesthesia is ?
questions.solution:
Topical anesthesia and hemostatic agents

See the list below:

Glycopyrrolate

Oxymetazoline 0.05%

Epinephrine 1:1,000 to 1:100,000

Lidocaine 4%

Cocaine 4%.

Tetracaine 2%

Local infiltration.

See the list below:

Lidocaine 1% without epinephrine (for nasal tip)

Lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 1:100,000 or without epinephrine (for repair of sides or superior portion of nose)

Nerve block

See the list below:

Lidocaine 1% without epinephrine

Mepivacaine 3%

Bupivacaine 0.5%

Other equipment

See the list below:

Cotton swabs or gauze

Forceps

Needle, 27 gauge

Syringe, 5 mL

Positioning

See the list below:

A seated position is ideal for most patients.

A supine position is acceptable for patients who cannot sit upright.

Mepivacaine is not used topically. It can be used topically but only in large doses. Thus option b is true.

Tag1 : Nose, pharmacology

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:542.

questions.text: Complete craniofacial separation is used in which type of facial fractures?
questions.solution:
Le Fort Type I

Transverse fracture through the maxilla above the roots of the teeth, separating teeth from the upper face. These can be unilateral or bilateral.

Le Fort Type II

These fractures extend superiorly in the midface to include the nasal bridge, maxilla, lacrimal bones, orbital floor, and rim. They are pyramidal fractures with teeth at the base and nasal bone at the apex. These fractures are typically bilateral.

Le Fort Type III

This type of fracture starts at the bridge of the nose and extends posteriorly along the medial wall of the orbit and the floor of the orbit, and then through the lateral orbital wall and the zygomatic arch. The fractures run parallel with the base of the skull, separating the entire midfacial skeleton from the cranial base. This discontinuity between the skull and the face is termed craniofacial dissociation. This may be associated with a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak.

Tag1 : Nose, Facial skeleton trauma

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:215.
